text: What is the best way to access other market for the same game, say access Place market when i process Win market? I'm currently using "event_processing", but it will feed all the markets under the same event. I don't know horse racing, but for greyhound racing, it will pull out all the games on the same track for the whole day, as the event is defined by track and date. So I'm getting a lot of unrelated racing market. Anyway to get other market with are just related  to current processing market?

text: <https://liampauling.github.io/flumine/quickstart/#event-processing>

The `Market` object contains a helper method for accessing other event linked markets:
```place_market = market.event["PLACE"]```

elements.text: The
Market
object contains a helper method for accessing other event linked markets:
place_market = market.event["PLACE"]

text: Yes, that is what I'm using. But it returns a list of Place markets, which are all under same event, but just one of them is linked to the current Win market. text: Does BFLW's streaming code handle missed heartbeats and auto-resubscribe? Or does the user have to write some kind of checking?

elements.text: Does BFLW's streaming code handle missed heartbeats and auto-resubscribe? Or does the user have to write some kind of checking?

text: The socket timeout is used instead, resubscribe is not auto but there is an example in examples in how it should be done

text:
It was but has recently been bumped to <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/eb08f1c400c0c5d61dacfd618aa93d5aceec15ac/betfairlightweight/endpoints/streaming.py#L26|64s> to solve another problem, you can reduce this to a value just above your heartbeat value (maybe we should add this dynamically after connection)

```betfair_socket = trading.streaming.create_stream(timeout=11)```

elements.text: It was but has recently been bumped to

betfair_socket = trading.streaming.create_stream(timeout=11)

text: was it increased because people were getting socket timeouts on very slow markets? if so shouldn't they just use heartbeats?

elements.text: was it increased because people were getting socket timeouts on very slow markets? if so shouldn't they just use heartbeats?

text: It needs to be above 15 to correctly get the timeout message on connection but this was to help poor networks where the socket was timing out when the server was still happy

elements.text: It needs to be above 15 to correctly get the timeout message on connection but this was to help poor networks where the socket was timing out when the server was still happy

text: When should one use a market_filter and when a streaming_market_filter?

elements.text: When should one use a market_filter and when a streaming_market_filter?

text:
If you're using Flumine or BFLW for streaming, use the streaming market filter. If you're just making API calls with BFLW use the market filter. In either case you can skip them all together and just pass a dict with the relevant parameters if you prefer.

There are two filters because the permitted parameters for streaming are more restrictive than for the API. So using the streaming filter will trigger an error if you try to use (for example) competition_ids, which is a valid parameter for API calls.

elements.text:
If you're using Flumine or BFLW for streaming, use the streaming market filter. If you're just making API calls with BFLW use the market filter. In either case you can skip them all together and just pass a dict with the relevant parameters if you prefer.

There are two filters because the permitted parameters for streaming are more restrictive than for the API. So using the streaming filter will trigger an error if you try to use (for example) competition_ids, which is a valid parameter for API calls.
